reviewText: Entertaining biker movie with some fine acting from Sheen, Madsen, Vance and co.  Fiorentino looks great. Lots of action and a plausible script. For that, you could add a star. I enjoyed this enough when I first saw it to search out the source for the story. After all, the narrater tells you at the end of the movie that the story you've just seen is true, and even tells you what happened to the major characters. For that blatant lying, you can knock off 2 stars.This film is "inspired" by the actions of one Anthony Tait (for the full story, get the book Hell's Angels Into The Abyss by Yves Lavigne). He was not an abused child as was Sheen's character Daniel Saxon. He was not a cop, though he always wanted to be one, (like Virgil, portrayed by Leon Rippy). Tait was an Alaskan (not Arizona) biker who liked to play cop and snitch to the local police. He belonged to a biker club called the Brothers which was absorbed by the Hell's Angels on Dec. 18, 1982. This gave the cops a snitch inside the Angels. Tait was a likable guy and quickly made friends and before long associated with top Angels like Sonny Barger. The Feds jumped on the opportunity of having a man inside the Hell's Angels. Tait got various bikers to sell him weapons and drugs. They got busted and served various amounts of jail time. No murdered girls in armed robberies, no beating up fellow cops, and while there was a reporter, there was no romance and the real person was nothing like the one portrayed by Fiorentino.There you have it. Take this movie as fictional entertainment. Do not buy into the true story tripe. Makes you wonder how much is really true in all those other movies claiming to be based on true stories, events, people etc. Doesn't it?
summary: Entertaining Movie, But Very Little Truth
Title: N/A

reviewText: Viewed: 10/11Rate: 710/11: Certainly a much better film than Harley Davidson and the Marlboro Man, Beyond the Law is an interesting but mundane look at an undercover cop infiltrating the underworld of bikers and its subculture. Why I say the word "mundane" is because we've seen it all before, starting with probably Serpico. So, the topic is nothing new. Moreover, Charlie Sheen, although his films are always watchable, still fails to be deep as an actor as usual, and it has always been the biggest flaw of his career. I just find it so odd, and maybe not, that Michael Madsen decided to do a film called Donnie Brasco after rehashing the same topic already four years earlier in Beyond the Law. At least, I liked him much better in the former, a real good piece of work, similar to that kind of conflict that Johnny Utah had with Bodhi. Another problem with Beyond the Law is that it's not all that convincing. If Larry Ferguson could bring that real biker look to the film like how Michael Mann did for The Jericho Mile with the real prisoners of Folsom State Penitentiary, that would have brought a new respect for the film as a whole. So, it's kind of disappointing. Also, Charlie never really fit in or pass for a real biker because he looks too clean to me. However, I do like the film regardless because the subject matter is interesting, and Charlie Sheen makes it interesting to watch. Watching him to act is almost like seeing his anger for real like how it was for him the past year or so. But of course, it's nothing new due to his long history of alcohol and drug abuse and woman beating ways. Already scarred by her performance in The Last Seduction, I feel Linda Fiorentino does nothing remarkable for Beyond the Law except to give Charlie a gratuitous sex scene. All in all, I did enjoy watching Beyond the Law, and it was worth my time.

reviewText: This is a good movie based on a true story. Charlie sheen is thrown into an undercover situation with very little training - two people could blow his cover at any time. Some might find the bike-building scene as a distraction, but I liked it. I think the portrait of some of the nuances of biker groups was rich in detail. Only complaint is that the biker "babes" in the movie were not accurate. Come on we all know biker babes are hot (my Mom is a biker babe) but the ones in the movie were - let's say, "lacking". Another non-intended comic point was the redneck bar scene. Charlie storms into a bar filled with "the meanest rednecks you ever seen" and they are all wearing pressed oxfords and loafers. But maybe that's the way rednecks dress in AZ? Charlie plays this multi-dimensional character very well. Overall, a good story well told.

reviewText: Beyond the law is based on the true story of a cop that goes undercover and infiltrates a outlaw motorcycle club. In my opinion this is Charlie sheens best movie and one of the best biker movies. Beyond the law is filled with a rockin soundtrack, nice bikes, some great acting, some humor and plenty of action. Charlie sheen does a great job of portraying a person being consumed by what he originally intended to fight. My favorite scene by far is the sequence when virgil helps sheens character build his bike. I think anyone interested in bikes our biker culture would enjoy this movie.

reviewText: Charlie Sheen plays a law enforcement officer that goes undercover in order to infiltrate a notorious motorcycle gang. His character has a harder time keeping his real life and undercover life separate because of some legitimate psychological baggage her carries around from childhood. You can see where his character seems to forget he is a cop and goes too far at times. This takes him to close to the edge where he realizes he has to come out or he may never re-gain his normal life.Michael Madsen does a fantastic job as being the leader of the motorcycle club. Even though you know he is the leader of this dangerous gang of felons and the worse of them all. He and the director give his character an edge that almost makes him likable. Showing that evil does have a seductive side.This film is based on a true story of Police Officer Dan Saxon who went undercover for two and half years in order to make his case. It resulted in 498 arrest and 497 convictions. Though the screenwriters have taken liberties with some embellishment, it is a pretty accurate peak inside a Motorcycle clubs life in the mid seventies.

reviewText: Some time ago i saw a clip on YouTube on this movie and it looked real good,not so.I thought that Sheen was Pres once he got into the club,by beating up Blood,again not so.I also wanted to hear more dialog on this and not some steady drowned out music.I will say one thing about Sheen,he did look like a biker especially with those goggles,and the beard was a nice touch too.This film has low volume even with all the bikes,and there were a lot of them.The start reminded me of Electra Glide In Blue with Robert Blake on his bike.This clocked in at 108m not much for extras either,only two.I was quite disappointed in this film especially with the sound,i thought the sound would be right in your face with that many bikers.I wouldn't recommend this unless you are a Charlie Sheen fan.I was also hoping that Blood would get his,only worse than what was done to him.He got off too easy if you ask me.

reviewText: Okay, this role isn't WALL STREET or PLATOON, but Charlie Sheen kicks butt in this film about a screwed up cop who goes undercover with a bike gang.  Sound familiar?  It should, as this genre has been made a hundred times.  This movie, however, is one of the best.  And since it was based (very) loosely on a true story then that much the better.My favorite actor in the film, though, is a thoroughly bad-assed Michael Madsen as the antagonist.  He spews perfect timing as the leader of the biker gang.Additionally, Leon Rippy does a great job as sidekick "Virgil", who is probably the most believable character in the film.  Also, Dennis Burkley (a wonderful bit actor that will surely be recognized) is perfectly cast as "Oatmeal".  Lastly, it is always good to have Rip Torn in any movie, lending heavyweight acting to any role.Simply, this is a keeper and a must see.  Hey, I'm a just a guy...
summary: Another 4-Star Movie for Guys Who Like Movies...

reviewText: Since the quality of Hollywood is so poor lately, I have taken to watching the older B movies, and this was a good one.  The storyline wavered between "iffy" and good, as so many of the movies of this period did, but I'm okay with that if the acting is good.  Early Sheen is not as good as some of the other Brat Packers, but; as I said, given the quality of Hollywood movies nowadays, I'm having fun watching some of the 1980 B movies.

reviewText: Considering it's free if you are a Prime member - and it's from 21 years ago - movie wasn't as bad as I thought it might.  Don't expect documentary quality realism, and as usual for Hollywood - lots of stereotypes.  But there were some good little moments, and I enjoyed seeing the bikes.  One day gonna get  me one of them old Springers, lol.....Charlie Sheen when he wants to be is a good actor - if you like Charlie you will LIKE this movie - and Linda is sexy as usual - if not or you don't care about bike movies - probably would take a pass.It's definitely not a family pic, more like a weeknight -  couple of  beers movie.What it does capture is the quick way life (in general) especially in these kinds of situations - can turn on a damn DIME....good to bad, from life to death, and even from sadness to brotherhood/happiness.Based on the few hardcore bikers I ever ran across - I'm not really buying the 'based on a true story' but I'm sure some similar things have happened.I thought the little backstory about Saxon helped a little to keep the movie from just being a formula.One thing WAS true about this movie - Bikers can be the best, most loyal friends/family in the world, with the most heart than anybody - but if you get on their BAD side - God help you.Enjoy, and Watch out for  those cagers :D(Big Al)
summary: Kind of like a 90's  Biker version of "Departed"
